revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use American English|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox military person |name=Wilhelm Lemke |birth_date={{birth date|1920|9|27|df=y}} |death_date={{death date and age|1943|12|4|1920|9|27|df=y}} |image=Wilhelm Lemke.jpg |caption=Wilhelm Lemke |birth_place=[[Arnswalde]], [[Weimar Republic]] |death_place=near [[Dodewaard]], [[Netherlands]] |placeofburial=[[Ysselsteyn German war cemetery]], Netherlands
(Block CW—Row 1—Grave 24) |nickname= |allegiance={{flag|Nazi Germany}} |branch={{Luftwaffe}} |serviceyears=1939–43 |rank=[[Hauptmann]] |unit=[[JG 3]] |commands=9./[[JG 3]], II./[[JG 3]] |battles=World War II *[[Operation Barbarossa]] *[[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] *[[Defense of the Reich]] |awards=[[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves]] |laterwork=}} '''Wilhelm Lemke''' (27 September 1920 – 4 December 1943) was a ''[[Luftwaffe]]'' [[flying ace]] of [[World War II]]. Lemke was credited with 131 aerial victories—that is, 131 aerial combat encounters resulting in the destruction of the enemy aircraft. All but six of his victories were claimed over the [[Soviet Air Forces]] in 617 combat missions.Spick 1996, p. 230. Born in [[Arnswalde]], Lemke joined the military service in the ''Luftwaffe'' of the [[Third Reich]] in 1939. Following flight training, he was posted to 9. ''[[Organization of the Luftwaffe (1933–1945)#Staffel|Staffel]]'' (squadron) of [[Jagdgeschwader 3|''Jagdgeschwader'' 3]] (JG 3—3rd Fighter Wing). He flew his first combat missions in [[Operation Barbarossa]], the German invasion of the Soviet Union, and claimed his first aerial victory on 26 June 1941. There, after 59 aerial victories, he was awarded the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross]] on 12 September 1942. He was given command as ''[[Staffelkapitän]]'' (squadron leader) of 9. ''Staffel'' on 11 August 1942. On 16 March 1943, he was credited with his 100th aerial victory. Four months later, on 28 July 1943, he claimed his 125th and last victory on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]]. Lemke was subsequently relocated to the [[Western Front (World War II)|Western Front]], where he flew in the [[Defense of the Reich]] and claimed six further victories. In mid-November 1943, he was appointed ''[[Gruppenkommandeur]]'' (group commander) of the II. ''[[Luftwaffe Organization#Gruppe|Gruppe]]'' (2nd group) of JG 3 "Udet"; he was awarded the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves]] on 25 November. Lemke was [[killed in action]] on 4 December 1943 northwest of [[Nijmegen]] in combat with [[United States Army Air Forces]] fighters. ==Early life and career== Lemke, the son of a [[civil servant]], was born on 27 September 1920 in Gundelsdorf near [[Arnswalde]], in what was then the [[Free State of Prussia]] of the [[Weimar Republic]] (today Choszczno in Poland). He joined the military service of the ''[[Luftwaffe]]'' as a ''[[Fahnenjunker]]'' (cadet) on 15 November 1939.Obermaier 1989, p. 59. Following fighter pilot training, he was promoted to ''[[Leutnant]]'' (second lieutenant) on 1 April 1941.Stockert 1998, p. 174.{{refn|Flight training in the ''Luftwaffe'' progressed through the levels A1, A2 and B1, B2, referred to as A/B flight training. A training included theoretical and practical training in aerobatics, navigation, long-distance flights and [[dead-stick landing]]s. The B courses included high-altitude flights, instrument flights, night landings, and training to handle the aircraft in difficult situations.Bergström, Antipov & Sundin 2003, p. 17.|group="Note"}} ==World War II== ===Eastern Front=== Lemke was posted to a front-line unit in 1941, almost two years after the start of World War II. His unit was 9. ''[[Organization of the Luftwaffe (1933–1945)#Staffel|Staffel]]'' (squadron) of [[Jagdgeschwader 3|''Jagdgeschwader'' 3]] (JG 3—3rd Fighter Wing).For an explanation of ''Luftwaffe'' unit designations see [[Organization of the Luftwaffe (1933–1945)|Organization of the ''Luftwaffe'' during World War II]]. In preparation for [[Operation Barbarossa]], the German invasion of the Soviet Union, JG 3 under the command of ''[[Major (Germany)|Major]]'' (major) [[Günther Lützow]] was relocated east. Lemke claimed two Soviet [[Tupolev SB|Tupolev SB-2]] bombers shot down on 26 June 1941—his first aerial victories.Prien & Stemmer 1996, p. 110. He was awarded the [[Iron Cross]] 2nd Class ({{lang|de|''Eisernes Kreuz zweiter Klasse''}}) on 4 July 1941 and Iron Cross 1st Class ({{lang|de|''Eisernes Kreuz erster Klasse''}}) on 20 July. By 26 August 1941, Lemke had accumulated 15 aerial victories. On this day, flying [[Messerschmitt Bf 109]] F-2 (''Werknummner'' 8245—factory number), he was hit and wounded in the [[Human abdomen|abdomen]] during combat with Soviet bombers but managed to make an emergency landing.Prien & Stemmer 1996, p. 449. On 3 November 1941, while convalescing, he was awarded the [[Ehrenpokal der Luftwaffe|Honor Goblet of the Luftwaffe]] ({{lang|de|''Ehrenpokal der Luftwaffe''}}). He returned to active service on 17 February 1942 and was posted to 8. ''Staffel'' of JG 3 "Udet".{{refn|On 1 December 1941, JG 3 was given the honorary name "Udet" following the suicide of World War I fighter pilot and ''Luftwaffe'' ''[[Generalleutnant]]'' [[Ernst Udet]].Prien & Stemmer 2002, p. 12.|group="Note"}} On 31 March 1942, Lemke claimed his 20th aerial victory.Stockert 1998, p. 175. He claimed three [[Lavochkin-Gorbunov-Gudkov LaGG-3]] fighters shot down in combat with 6 UAG (6th Soviet strike aviation group—''Udarnaya Aviatsionnaya Gruppa'') on 4 April.Bergström & Mikhailov 2001, p. 95. He was credited with his 30th victory on 24 June 1942, and aerial victories 39 to 42 on 29 July. Subsequently, he was nominated for the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross]] ({{lang|de|''Ritterkreuz des Eisernen Kreuzes''}}) by his 8. ''Staffel''. He was given command as ''[[Staffelkapitän]]'' (squadron leader) of his former 9. ''Staffel'' on 11 August 1942, leading this unit until 5 November 1943. Lemke claimed his 57th victory on 7 September 1942, his 58th one day later, and his 59th victory on 11 September. The next day, he was awarded the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross. On 27 December, he involuntarily [[Aerial ramming|rammed]] a LaGG-3 in combat. By 31 December 1942 his score had increased to 90 victories. As well as his aerial victories, he was credited with the destruction of aircraft on the ground, as well as three tanks, three fuel trucks, eleven other trucks, three [[Katyusha rocket launcher|''Katyusha'' rocket launchers]], one anti-tank gun, and two mortars. On 16 March 1943, he claimed his 100th aerial victory, a [[Lavochkin La-5]] fighter.Weal 2001, p. 66. Lemke was the 35th ''Luftwaffe'' pilot to achieve the century mark.Obermaier 1989, p. 243. He was promoted to ''[[Oberleutnant]]'' (first lieutenant) on 1 April 1943 and to ''[[Hauptmann]]'' (captain) on 1 June. He was credited with his last victory on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] on 28 July 1943, taking his total to 125. ===Western Front and death=== [[File:Combatbox.gif|thumb|right|upright=1.4|Combat box of a 12-plane B-17 squadron. Three such boxes completed a 36-plane group box.
1. Lead Element
2. High Element
3. Low Element
4. Low Low Element]] On 2 August 1943, JG 3 "Udet" began transferring to [[Western Front (World War II)|Western Front]] and flew in [[Defense of the Reich]]. Lemke claimed two [[United States Army Air Forces]] (USAAF) [[Republic P-47 Thunderbolt]] fighters shot down on 17 August during the [[Schweinfurt–Regensburg mission]], his first on the Western Front.Weal 2012, p. 38.Weal 2013, p. 60. By 14 October 1943, he was credited with one victory and two ''Herausschüsse'' (separation shots)—a severely damaged heavy bomber forced to separate from his [[combat box]], which was counted as an aerial victory—over [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress]] bombers. On that day, he claimed his 129th and 130th victory, one of which was a ''Herausschuss'', over B-17s on their [[second Raid on Schweinfurt]].Weal 2013, p. 62. In mid-November 1943, Lemke was appointed ''[[Gruppenkommandeur]]'' (group commander) of the II. ''[[Luftwaffe Organization#Gruppe|Gruppe]]'' (2nd group) of JG 3 "Udet". He succeeded ''Major'' [[Kurt Brändle]], who had been [[killed in action]] on 3 November. Lemke surrendered command of 9. ''Staffel'' to ''Leutnant'' [[Ekkehard Tichy]] and took command of the ''Gruppe'' a few days later at the [[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol|Schiphol airfield]], near [[Amsterdam]] in the Netherlands.Prien & Stemmer 2003, p. 195.Prien & Stemmer 1996, p. 443. He was awarded the [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves]] ({{Lang|de|''Ritterkreuz des Eisernen Kreuzes mit Eichenlaub''}}) on 25 November, the 338th officer or soldier of the Wehrmacht so honored. On 30 November 1943 at 11:25 am, he achieved his 131st and final aerial victory over a P-47.Prien & Stemmer 2003, p. 398. Lemke was killed in action in his Bf 109 G-6 (''Werknummner'' 410558) on 4 December 1943 near [[Dodewaard]], {{convert|12|km|mi|sp=us}} northwest [[Nijmegen]]. His mission was to lead an attack of 55 aircraft on a fighter intercept mission against USAAF fighters escorting [[Eighth Air Force]] bombers.McFarland & Newton 2006, pp. 135–136. He was shot down by P-47 Thunderbolts of the [[352nd Fighter Group]].Weal 1999, p. 62. Lemke was buried at the German war cemetery [[Ysselsteyn]] in the Netherlands. ==Aerial victory credits== Lemke was credited with 131 aerial victories claimed in 617 combat missions, 125 of which were on the Eastern Front and included 28 [[Ilyushin Il-2]] [[ground-attack aircraft]]. {{legend2|#e3d9ff|This and the – (dash) indicates unwitnessed aerial victory claims for which Lemke did not receive credit. |border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}
{{legend2|#fbec5d;|This along with the * (asterisk) indicates an ''Herausschuss'' (separation shot)—a severely damaged heavy bomber forced to separate from his combat box which was counted as an aerial victory.|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}}

==Awards== * [[Iron Cross]] (1939) ** 2nd Class (4 July 1941)Thomas 1998, p. 21. ** 1st Class (20 July 1941) * ''[[Ehrenpokal der Luftwaffe]]'' (Honor Goblet of the ''Luftwaffe'') on 3 November 1941 as ''[[Leutnant]]'' and pilotPatzwall 2008, p. 134. * [[Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves]] ** Knight's Cross on 12 September 1942 as ''Leutnant'' and ''[[Staffelkapitän|Staffelführer]]'' of the 9./''Jagdgeschwader'' 3 "Udet"Fellgiebel 2000, p. 288.Von Seemen 1976, p. 220.{{refn|According to Scherzer on 19 September 1942 as pilot in the 8./''Jagdgeschwader'' 3 "Udet".Scherzer 2007, p. 501.|group="Note"}} ** 338th Oak Leaves on 25 November 1943 as ''[[Hauptmann]]'' and ''[[Gruppenkommandeur]]'' of the II./''Jagdgeschwader'' 3 "Udet"Fellgiebel 2000, p. 75.Von Seemen 1976, p. 39.{{refn|According to Scherzer as ''[[Staffelkapitän]]'' in the III./''Jagdgeschwader'' 3 "Udet".|group="Note"}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="Note"}} Pennsylvania |publisher=Schiffer Military History |isbn=978-0-7643-1681-4 }} * {{cite book |last1=Prien |first1=Jochen |last2=Stemmer |first2=Gerhard |year=2003 |title=Jagdgeschwader 3 "Udet" in WWII: II./JG 3 in Action with the Messerschmitt Bf 109 |location=Atglen, Pennsylvania |publisher=Schiffer Military History |isbn=978-0-7643-1774-3 }} * {{Cite book |last=Scherzer |first=Veit |year=2007
